title: Mini Bench Vice Jaw Protectors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Some vice jaw protectors/soft jaws for a small 60mm hobby bench vice. 
Use the vice jaw protectors to avoid damaging delicate objects when you grip them.

Vice:
The small bench vice shown has no identifying branding or markings on it. In order to check if the jaw protectors will fit your little hobby vice, the pertinent info on the jaws is:
  • Width: 60mm
  • Jaw height: One is 11.1mm, the other 12.1mm. Hence there are two models, just plate them up together and print them both at the same time.
  • Jaw depth: The protectors clip onto a little lip on the top of the vice jaws. The depth of this lip is ~3.1mm.
    • Printing:
    The jaws are printed without support. The only overhang is the 45Â° angle of the clip and that prints without support.
    Layer height: 0.15mm
    The sides should be one wall thickness depending on your extruder type.
    Perimeters: 2
    The jaw faces are 0.8mm thick, so if you print with min 3 top & bottom layers, then the jaw face should print effectively solid, so your infill selection doesn't matter. Measure your vice jaw height. There are two .stl files. One with 11.15mm jaw height, and the other with 12.15mm jaw height. Print two of the jaws that match your vice. Use:
    Snap in place, hold delicate parts with less chance of damaging them. Don't forget you can also add masking tape or similar to the vice jaws (or protectors/soft jaws) if you are worried about damaging the finish of your object.

title: Printrbot X Axis Belt Tensioner (No Zip Ties)

description.text: Allows you to adjust the tension on your x-axis belt by turning screws. A belt clip is used instead of zip ties to retain the ends of the belt.

1) Remove the x-axis belt ends from the extruder carriage.
2) Place the casing onto the extruder carriage so that the belt pass-through hole aligns with the one in the carriage.
3) Route the x-axis belt ends up through the carriage/casing assembly.
4) Open up the screw holes on the insert with a 5/32" drill. Insert a 3/4" 6-32 bole through the hole and attach a matching nut on the bolt. Snug the nut down so that it seats into the hex nut recess in the insert.
5) Remove the 6-32 screws for now.
6) Place the insert into the casing and feed the x-axis belt ends though the insert and pull it snug. Push the insert all the way into the casing until it rests on the bottom.
7) Pull the x-axis belt a tight as you feel comfortable doing.  Slide on the belt clip as low as possible.
8) Reinstall the 6-32 screws. Adjust the belt tension so that it is the proper tightness... nice and snug but not so tight as to put excessive strain on the system components, or to stall the x-axis stepper motor. Somewhere around 1/4" deflection on the belt before you're really tugging on it.
*Most of the verbage is rickmellor.  Thanks Rick!

author: wstein

description.text: Since herringbone gears need to have one side floating, I have designed some helical gears to replace the printrbot extruder gears.  Helical gears provide smoother power transmission than spur gears.  My prints improved immediately after switching from the lasercut spur gears.

Simply bolt them on and enjoy.  (Note: this is for the printrbot LC.  I am sure it may fit others but I am not sure which ones.  The large gear takes a 5/16" bolt.  I slightly undersized the hole so I could drill it for the perfect fit.  The small gear takes an M3 nut and screw.)

comments.text: are these any better than the injected molded gears printrbot has just released? Im not sure if you have tried those. I have a LC V2 and so far no problems with the Injected Gears. Im curious though If Id get better prints with these gears.
comments.author: Lookitsneil

comments.text: I would suspect that well engineered injected molded gears would be superior.  The laser cut gears they use to have were not good at all.  The thing that increase the quality of my prints more than anything was a x and y belt tensioner.

comments.text: I picked up a pair of the laser cut spur gears and they have a noticeably thinner tooth at the base than my gears.  I wonder if that may cause the difference you are seeing (vs the helical vs spur).  The thinner teeth may not run as smoothly if they are not designed right.
comments.author: Drawcut

comments.text: I have been printing with these gears for at least 20 machine hours and nothing has budged.
comments.author: Drawcut

comments.text: I agree that helical gears will give you a higher overall Contact Ratio vs spur gears.  What Helical Contact Ratio do you get with these?  But I don't agree that helicals will be better for lower quality teeth.  I've never heard of or seen anything in any of the AGMA gearing standards that would support that.
comments.author: nseward

comments.text: First, I am not an expert so take all of this with a grain of salt. The contact ratio for the spur gear is 1.3 and the helical gear is 3.3. http://www.donkersdesigns.com/gear%20calculation.htmlhttp://www.donkersdesigns.com/... To be honest, I haven't spent enough time with this to understand the significance of these two numbers. (The general wisdom seems to be that larger contact ratios are associated with quieter gears.)

comments.text: That's a great gear design website - it's going in my bookmarks.  I do gear design as part of my job so I am lucky to have access to professional software and references.  I think you're on the right track here but maybe not entirely for the reasons you might think.  I hope I don't come across badly.

description.text: Bike

I'm so proud of my small mount for my ipod shuffle. It was always such a mess to charge, with the wire and the usb connector, and took 2 hands to plug in and out. Just no weight to the charger port and would fall over when the wire got kinked. Well, not any more. This mount can be screwed into a table or use double stick tape. Mine printed great on .2 layers and slow 20m/s speed.  
The clips on it are extra tough and will not bend, but the base/bottom is real thin and will bend just enough to snap it in. This means you may not be able to remove it once it's mounted without un-mounting it, but why would you? Get the charger base mounted where you want and leave. You always know where it it?  
Enjoy, thanks, Rick.

title: Mini Desktop for Raspberry Pi or similar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a screen / power supply combination for use with Raspberry Pis, Banana Pis or similar single-board computers. I used bjoerngieslers touch monitor case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:298272) and parts from limas monitor holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398147) together with some housing parts for this power supply which can supply sufficient 12 V power for the display and 3.7 Amperes @ 5VDC which is more than enough for even powering a banana pi with a SATA hard drive: http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/Nzg5OTQ2OTk-/Stromversorgung/Netzgeraete/Festspannungs_Netzgeraete/Schaltnetzteil_VOLTEK_SPEC7188B.html

You will need:
  • boern's display housing (front and back)
  • olima's monitor arm and the mounting plate for the case (I cut away the second one I didn't need in Cura)
  • one of each STLs of this thing (monitor base, end caps 1 and 2 for the power supply and the 3 lids)
  • a 12 mm diameter push button switch, e.g. this one: http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/MTM1OTc1OTk-/Bauelemente_Bauteile/Mechanische_Bauelemente/Schalter_Taster/Einbau_Druckschalter_PBS_11A.html
  • a 9-pin sub-d female connector
  • a 9-pin sub-d male connector with housing
  • a micro usb cable for powering the single board computer
  • a piece of cable with fitting power plug for the display module
  • M3x10 mm screws and nuts
  • M6 screws and nuts
    • Screw the monitor base onto the power supply with 3 M3x10 screws; mount the sub d female connector and the switch to the power supply end piece and connect them with the cables of the power supply. I soldered the white and grey cable to the switch which allows me to easily switch on and off the power supply. Remove the M3 screw at the end of the power supply opposite to the AC socket and slide the ends onto the supply. Slide in the lids at the bottom and secure everything with some drops of glue. Mount the display into the housing as described in bjoern's thing and attach it to the power supply with olima's arm. With the cables and the male plug, connect the display and the Pi to the power supply and have fun ;-)

comments.text: Cool build, how much did the electronics cost?
comments.author: AutogyroGuy

comments.text: I paid 2,50 € for the power supply and about 55 € for the display. Switch, cables and connectors were about 2 €, so everything together was less than 60 Euros. Together with a Pi 2, a HDMI cable and a simple Keyboard/Mouse you get a decent Linux PC for about 100 Euros ;-)

Anywho.. I hope you challenge yourself and make one. You will learn a great deal through the process I promise.. BTW the wheel can be any diameter- the Hall Sensor just gets mounted on the end anyway and it dictates timing. -- use foam core it rocks....

comments.text: Hmm...perhaps I don't understand what you're saying (I don't see how a cyclical animation has a start frame, for one thing), but I suspect you're over-thinking the zoetrope. When using a stepper motor, you really don't need the sensors. (Alternately, using a sensor, you only need a simple motor).

author: n9jcv

title: Cupcake Gen3 Extruder Controller and Relay Board Mount

description.text: This is for mounting the Extruder Controller and Relay board to the side of a Cupcake CNC. The boards stick out a bit above the top of the side panel, but are still below the Z belt. The big improvement over other EC board mounts is that the bracket mounts to the Cupcake body with two screws instead of one, so it won't pivot the way my previous mounting solution did.

I used 10mm M3 screws. The bracket will hold all of the nuts captive, but I left out the nuts to mount the boards and just threaded the screws into the plastic holes, which were more than tight enough. If you want to use the nuts, you should either use 12mm screws for the boards or modify the parameters in the scad file.
Note: this mount puts the leads for the RJ-45 connector on the EC sitting over the head of one of the side panel's mounting screws. To avoid the possibility of a short if the board flexes, you should put a piece of tape over these leads.

author: SJCLibraries

title: Raspberry Pi camera support for the SmartCore 3D Printer

description.text:
I use OctoPi on a Raspberry Pi computer as a 3D printing server on my SmartCore printer by SmartFriendz, and it has a nice webcam and timelapse feature, and I wanted to use some articulated support to set this mini camera on the printing board so it would always be aimed at the object being printed.
I found some RPI cam supports and articulated arms ideas, but it needed some tweaking and adjustments to fit my need, so I made this one… As I built it in Blender, I included the .blend source file so you can easily modify it. You can, for instance, increase the length by using two adjustable arm sections instead of one, and make a different base plate to adjust it to different printers. I guess it would also be cool to add supports on the camera case for LED lighting, I'd be curious to see that if you want to make that kind of improvements, so please let me know! ;) I was, at first, inspired by this other RPIcam mount (I hope it's alright if I made a derivative version from this) : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:504823

The arm length is adjustable, and there are three points of rotation so it's really easy to setup. You'll just need two wood screws to put the base part under the printing board, four m3 x 30 steel screws (at least two with hexagonal heads) and four m3 wing nuts to assemble the arm.
The camera will, of course, need a longer cable than the one provided with the device. I use a 30cm one which is just perfect on my SmartCore.

description.text:
I've started sculpting base meshes which are fairly generic and can be used a a framework for future models. This shouldn't result in my work looking "samey" (well, I hope not) but it will save some time. For this entry, I shall focus on human faces' which unless very deformed (or have non-human elements added), follow a basic rule of proportion. I decided to start with a female head, neck and partial shoulders (what is also known as a bust) as there is a very complicated model I want to make in the future and I'd like to get practised with as many components as I can in advance. The theme I chose for this model is the Flapper. Here is a poem I found which describes the idea fairly well: The New Fashioned Girl Let them sing of the girls of the long, long ago,
Who were shocked if their elbows or stockings did show,
But I'll chant of the maidens whose ankles are free,
To show their half-socks and the shape of their knees,
Let them praise those back numbers who turned in their toes
And panted and fainted when MEN would propose;
Compared to the short-haired, bob-headed fry
Who meet all proposals with right to the eye.
Let them shed all their tears in a crocodile pour
For the simple simp sister who flourished in yore
But I'll cast my vote in the way that I feel -
For the girl self reliant, bright, snappy and REAL --Unknown You can read about this in my blog: http://www.southquay3d.com/index.php?route=news/article&news_id=17" This model when fully assembled is 14cm tall. She prints support free. She was sculpted in Blender.

Printed with .2 layer height.  
In addition to the printed parts, you will need a glue capable of bonding the material you are using.  
I advise attaching the jewel to the headband (there is a small square which acts as a placeholder) before attaching the headband to the head pieces.  The headband, the face and the head top all have arrows ont hem to show which direction in which to position them.

title: CharlStruder For E3D and J-Head on Prusa i3

description.text:
This is the DIYElectronics.co.za CharlStruder, A variant of the venerable Greg's Wade extruder. We found a bunch of other peoples designs each with there own merits, but none with all we wanted! We took these ideas as inspiration and decided to start from scratch and integrate them all into one complete unit! This is V1.0 and there may yet be more, but we think that this is the most complete extruder unit yet :). Thank you to all the other designs available, we tried to include you all. Features:
  • Standard Greg Wade design, used M8 hobbed bolt, 3x 608zz bearings, extruder springs, gregs wade style gears etc.
  • Two mounting options, standard Prusa i3 X Carriage and new Prusa i3 Rework 4 screw mount (need the rework 4 bearing carriage for that, see i3 Rework E3D Extruder)
  • Birdnose guidler quick release system, uses 2x M4x75 machine screws, cam style clamp, modified guidler and extruder that allows you to open the extruder without changing the extruder tension! (We were sick of unscrewing the standard gregs wade!) Filament changes and jams are now a breeze!
  • Changed geometry that moves the motor 90' and back such that the center of mass (COM) is more or less over the X-Axis shafts.
  • E3D / J-head moved upwards to allow more Z travel and bigger prints as well as reducing the moment force on the X-Carriage thus reducing -wobble- .
  • Improved E3D / J-head mounting clamp that makes installation and changing very easy and fast!
  • Extruder fan mount.
  • Drawn in supports and bridges, creates a perfect print with even the worst slicers!
  • Large stepper motor mounting slots allowing you plenty of movement to get good gear meshing.
    • Should fit standard Prusa i3 carriages and Rework carriages

Download the correct variant! Either the E3D or J-Head depending on your hot-end (J-head has slightly bigger mounting groove and is shorter than the E3D so the entire hot-end is moved down)
And the correct filament size: 1.75mm or 3.00mm Also download and print 1 each of the 3 birdnose files if you wish to use those. You will also need some gregs wades gears, there are many examples out there.. Other hardware needed:
  • 1x M8 Hobbed bolt + Nylock nut
  • ~10x M8 Washers
  • 3x 608zz skate bearing
  • 1x short 20mm M8 shaft to hold bearing in guidler
  • 2x M4x75 machine screws and some M4 washers
  • 2x M4 nuts
  • 2x 30mm strong extruder springs to go over M4's
  • 3x M3x12 screws for stepper motor mount
  • 1x M3x30 guidler screw
  • 2x M3x35 or longer screws for hotend mount
  • 3x M3 nuts
  • 6x M3 washers
    • Print in ABS or other high temp plastic with ~1mm wall thickness, 20-25% infill and 0.3mm layer height.

This is a simple pulley designed to be taped to walls to "pivot" string. You may be thinking, "Why on earth would I want to tape a pulley to my wall, amoebaboy123?" Well, my quizical internet traveler, I shall explain. Have you ever lain in bed late at night, gotten really tired and completely ready to sleep, but had to get up to turn off your light? Then you lose your will to sleep, and go back to pushing it off! Additionally, have you ever gotten up in the early morning, been unable to see while walking towards your lightswitch, and trip over something, or stub your toe because of the lack of light? On the off chance that neither have happened to you, they suck. This changes all that! Now, you just have to reach over and pull a string to turn your light on or off! If you are interested, dear reader, view the instructions!

Tape a pulley above and below your light switch, as well as two next to each other within arm's reach of your bed. Then, tape two pieces of string to the switch. You should then run one of the strings through the pulley above the switch, and then through one of the pulleys near your bed. Pull it until the slack on the string is minimal, and then tape the string to the wall, making sure to leave enough room on the string for your hand to grasp it. Next, run the other string through the pulley under the switch, then through the open pulley near your bed, and tape it to the wall again. Thats all, folks!   
PS: Before you ask, yes, I do very much like tape. :)

description.text:
I’m only a leisure weekend cyclist but a hard core cycling colleague of mine mentioned she took bananas on her long rides but it was always a pain to carry them. Taped to the frame was a bugger to undo ‘on the go’ and stuffed into back pouches meant they often got squashed during the ride – apparently. So, in my product designing spare time I came up with this crazy thing. Download the 3d file, print it out, fix to standard bike mounts and you're ready to go! Water and Banana only a finger tip away! Designed for small bananas only (need to keep ride weight down) Print at 0.2 or finer with high infill - needs to be strong (still in beta testing) No supports or raft needed (this will test your slicer and filament cooling fans) DISCLAIMER: this is first prototype and hasn't been extensively road tested.
PLEASE DO NOT use in ride situations where an unrestrained bananas could cause injury! UPDATE:
110616 v2 added.
Redesigned to be stronger and smaller - will fit with 150x150x150 build area but with cages to hold larger bananas. UPDATE:
110117
NanaBotCageCP3D_v3.stl added
Thanks to Thingiverse member http://www.thingiverse.com/FourMat/about
for a suggestion to separate banana holders to allow bottle cage to flex for different sizes of water bottles Enjoy!

comments.text: This is an awesome design.  I used a Prusa3d I3 MK2 with PLA, and the Prusa Edition of Slic3r, but i had to reduce the default speed to 50% while printing to prevent the warping and lifting on all of the overhanging edges of the curves.  Once It was printed I realized just how strong this beast is.  The only problem I have is that I use the Camelback Podium bottles and I have to jam them into the cage.  They are really hard to remove.  So much so that I think it will be too hard to remove while riding.   Standard generic bottles like a basic Trek version slide in and out OK.  My only suggestion would be to separate the unit between the banana cages to allow the cage to flex just slightly.  I think it will be more than strong enough to handle that and give a little forgiveness for different bottle types.  I'm trying to load the STL and split it, but am finding it a little difficult to load and edit such a complex mesh.  Think you can split it in the original CAD file?

It had taken anywhere from 18 to 20 hours to print on the various iterations I've tried.

author: joshuahirshman

description.text:
This Crossbow shoots marshmallows and is powered by large #64 rubber bands. It requires about 10 inches of 1/4 inch dowel and 2 12" x 24" sheets of 1/4 inch plywood, about four feet of string, and a 6"x"6 inch piece of 1/8 inch vaneer plywood (often sold as door skins) for the marshmallow cup.
The colors are just to help keep the pieces separate during design.
I was inspired by the decor at Disneyland's Tomorrowland, very retro 1950's sci-fi.

First you will need to Laser cut the pieces from 1/4 inch plywood ( actual thickness was 0.18 inches) Assemble the stock pieces with glue.
Assemble the arms of the bow with the spaces between, spiral to the center of the bow, and tri-lobed end toward the outside. The rubber bands will eventually be looped over these protrusions.
Assemble the trigger with parts spaced on either side of the trigger guard. You will need a small piece of 1/4 inch dowel as a holder for the marshmallow cup.
Attach the top and bottom to the stock, with the spacers at the front to keep them apart and stable. These spacers are where the other end of the rubber band will attach when assembled.
Assemble the cup (made of 1/8 in vaneer) with the hook (made of 1/4 inch plywood) out the back
Attach the bow arms with 1/4 inch dowel and keep in place with the small arrowhead shaped pieces.
Cut two strings long enough to span the bow. About 24 inches each.
Run string through the holes in the cup and tie them off on either side of the bow arms.
Attach rubber bands from the front spacers to the arm spaces. I used 3 #64 sized bands on each arm.
Attach a smaller rubber band from the back of the trigger through the stock and back tot he trigger. Tie it off so that the trigger returns after pulled.
Load marshmallow, fire at unobservant people. 8)

description.text:
45mm x 45mm square used for ripple/ring testing performed as part of 3DPrintBoard thread http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?9056-Marlin-Motion-Related-Configuration-h-Settings-for-MakerFarm-i3v In addition to sharp corners, the test object includes a variety of holes, notches, dimples and recesses on all four sides for the purpose of evaluating the effect printer or slicer settings can have on trailing edge ripple or ring. The 45mm perimeter size is intended to allow the printer to reach maximum configured speed before beginning to decelerate for the far end. Wall thickness is 1.75mm
Note that the depth of the various dimples and recesses likely varies. No gcode is provided since it would typically be sliced using different slicer settings.
Configure number of perimeters and extrusion width as required to prevent use of any zig zag or other non-solid infill that may contribute it's own artifact on the print results.

I fell in love with hotkey's Ninja Fridge Shuriken http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6383
and so designed a few of my own, and based some on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:323 I put holes in the middle to cut down on plastic a little. and beveled edges but tried to keep it to 60 degrees so you shouldnt have a problem printing them.

Each star should fit on a makerbot, the stars.stl is one file with all 10 stars on it, but you better have a big bed to print it! it is a 3 hour print for me but than you have 10 Shurikens! The magnets I am using are
http://www.fridgedoor.com/mabl25x25x15.html I put two magnets opposite facing for the big spots.. and crazy glue them all in place. I have not found any fridges that have a polarity so this has not been an issue. Oh, Hopefully your prints come out better than mine, it takes me about a minute a piece to clean them up with hobby knife. Print, Enjoy!

This is spare ammunition for a toy cannon. The original ammo were round balls. Given they were small lots of them ended up in the vacuum cleaner. I printed spares and now they are everywhere in our house :-)

Print with at least one perimeter and with a fill grade of at least 75% so they have some weight.
Tell your slicer to multiply the model on the printed to the amount you need. I printed them in PLA on a heated bed with a layer height of .25 mm.

title: Surface mount for zip ties , cable ties or string etc

description.text:
I needed to mount a computers case fan externally, flush, using cable ties. So I made this mount that can be glued or held on with sticky pads (like servo tape) and then the cable tie can be passed through it. Some cheaper cable ties can snap if you bend them too much so I gave a nice smooth radius for it to pass through.  
The hole should fit 5mm wide ties or smaller.  
I have now printed these and they are working spot on.Let me know if you want other sizes.  
The STL is a set of 4, I may do some other sizes and single item file.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/eI7V5b96I1M

Six film spools for use in respooling 120 film for 620 cameras.  Carefully cut the spools from the sprue - nail clippers work for that.
Suitable for SLS printing.  For a MakerBot-compatible spool, see the 2-piece version by ComradeQuiche.
The photo shows a standard 120 roll, a 120 roll re-spooled on a 620 spool, and an empty 620 spool. The 620 spools were printed by Shapeways in 'black, strong, flexible' plastic.

comments.text: Received my order of two of these (12 spools total). I found that a pair of toenail clippers made an adequate substitute for the side cutter pliers I don't have anymore. On a couple of the spools had to take some emery cloth to them to remove the burr left by the clippers.

description.text: 620 film spool

Spool for use in respooling 120 film for 620 cameras.  Suitable for SLS printing.  See the two-piece spool by ComradeQuiche for a MakerBot-compatible version.
The photo shows a standard 120 roll, a 120 roll re-spooled on a 620 spool, and an empty 620 spool.  The 620 spools were printed by Shapeways in 'black, strong, flexible' plastic.

comments.text: How would I modify this to create larger size spools?
comments.author: Shal0m

comments.text: I ordered one of these from shape ways and received it today. It looks just like one of the original meatl ones that came with the film. The only thing I noticed was that either the dimensions on the holes top and bottom is a little small or the printing process may leave some "over spray" or debris in the holes because it was tight fit to get the spool to load into the camera body (the film retention studs were "tight" fitting into the holes on my Kodak Tourist II Camera). Quickly resolved that issue by spinning a drill bit (counter clockwise) in the top and bottom hole. I assume the holes will probably enlarge with use. So I ordered from shapeways 2 of the 6 spool thingy that gketner drew up (find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67834)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... So those 12 will give me a total of 21 spools on hand (which will hopefully last for a life time).

Bei meinen Lüftern musste ich die maximale Leistung runterdrehen, da sonst soviel Luft gefördert würde, dass sonst der Extruder so stark abkühlt und kein Filament mehr extrudieren kann.

I bought a new smartphone, the Nokia Lumia 920, and found my old self-printed car-Mount begin too small. So I decided to design a new one using my increased knowledge of OpenSCAD and my better printing experience. This result is fully customizable, can load different smartphones and you can even add different holder-adapters. I decided to use two different Adapters - one to have the man stand on my desk and one to attach the man to the Ventilation of my car. You may create your own Adapters simply by creating a plate that you can screw to the back of the man - see the adapter-scad-file example.
My own Smartphone holder and the Galaxy Holder from Telepath inspired me with this Thing.

If you own a Lumia 920, simply print the provided "CarMountMen.stl". If you own another Smartphone, measure the width and the thickness of your Smartphone and use the customizer to create your personal holder. For the stand you may use the "CarAdapter.stl" or create your own Version. For simplicity I've added "StandAdapter.stl" which you may use to put the man on your desk. The "CarAdpater" has a slightly turned hole, so that the man Show in the direction of the Driver. The "StandAdapter" has this hole turned, so that the man can stand. Please see the Pictures - I don't know how to say that in english. ;)
I've used the "VentilationMountStick" to Mount it to my Ventilation and to put it on my desk. Then simply screw the Adapter to the man with some M3x16 or similar. The holes for the screws are countersunk so won't scratch your smartphone on the back. If you have any question - feel free to ask!

author: FDMTech

description.text:
The PPG is the sidearm used by B5 security on the Bablyon-5 TV show. I've tried to get the scale as accurate as I can, although it may need to be scaled down for cosplayers with smaller hands. The original prop was made from machined aluminum so getting the finish to read right is a big part of making it look good.  
Note: The image from TV and the basic design are copyrighted by others. My 3D model is a totally original creation inspired by their ideas.  
A nice modification would be for the "cap" and "body" to install magnets so they could snap together like they do on the show.

Print one of everything, except for medallions based on your taste. I used support for all parts although these things will probably print without support: heat sink, cap, trigger body, medallions. The body may also print without support or may not depending on your printer. The grip and muzzle will definitely need support.  
Before painting, glue the muzzle and cap into place. Now paint everything a glossy black base coat. Paint more as follows:  
For the trigger body, trigger, and heat sink: use a silver topcoat.  
For the combined body, muzzle and cap: mask off the parts that remain black. Since these were mostly circular I used small balls of modeling clay that I flattened enough to mask each area. Paint a silver topcoat and remove the masking.  
For the grip, mask off the textured area and lightly spray with burnt sienna.  
For the medallions paint lightly with a bronze metallic paint.  
To assemble just glue everything together. You may pick medallions that match your preference, but they don't matter much unless your printer is very detailed. I used the PsiCorp medallions which work pretty well as a replacement for the Pachmyar logos.

description.text:
Just moved the appropriate parts to a plate so they could be added to the robo group. Had a hard time finding a set that fit the robo. Since it has a non adjustable stepper, has to be the right size.
Reduced steps per mm about 250-300
Probably a better set available... but until it's posted in groups.... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46374
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5111 center nut holder on the large gear is a mm too small. not a problem with an exacto or something.
printed the small gear a TINY bit oversized to get tight fit on the driven gear.

title: Picatinny flashlight mount for Costco flashlight

description.text:
I use this for an airsoft gun, to mount a flashlight I bought at Costco (set of 3 for under $20).  There are many other similar designs on Thingiverse, but I had trouble using some of the files for editing the design, so I just designed my own in Viacad.  
The flashlight I used has a 29mm diameter, so standard 1-inch (25.4mm) scope rings would not work.  3D-printing to the rescue!  
In case anyone wants to modify the design for their own lights, I have included the STEP file.  I have never used STEP files, but Viacad can export them, so I hope it's useful.  If not, there's not much I can do to help.

I printed it with 20% infill, but probably should have used more, though it feels plenty strong as-is.  
Use 6-32 x 1/2" machine screws for the top clamp, and 6-32 x 1.25" machine screws for the mounting clamp.  
I printed it in PLA, but ABS might be better for use outside on sunny days, when PLA can get a little soft.  I'll just have to see how it goes.

comments.text: Nice and simple design!  Fit the rails on an MP9 and a Power Led Storm flashlight perfectly!!  Printed in PLA at 40% infill and super strong.
comments.author: rcjoseb

comments.text: Awesome job mate! Perfect fit with ABS on a g&g cm16r with a mounted xml-t6 light. (cheap amazon.com flashlight)

author: RandyR

description.text: Printed in PLA using 0.2 mm layer height and 50% in-fill.  Less in-fill can be used to reduce weight.
Control webcam lens with standard servo would be fun. See the video - http://youtu.be/27uGegRznfE. Next thing? Autofocusing the webcam, of course!

• Check your webcam board layout and servo dimension. I have an TGCam-C30 camera and a HS-322 compatible servo.
  • Print STL's or 'TGCam-C30_HS-322' for all.
  • Place your webcam board and servo onto 'servo_plate.'
  • Bolt 'board_plate' if you want.
  • Bolt servo_gear to your servo horn.
  • Attach lens_gear to the webcam lens.
    • Note
    The lens_gear in model files has 14mm diameter which is the outside diameter of the webcam lens.
    But I modified the lens_gear hole slightly bigger than the webcam lens and taping servral time the lens to make them holding tight.
    This would be a safer way not to break the webcam board and lens while attaching the lens_gear. But if you want, you can leave the lens_gear hole tight and trying to press it onto the lens by your vice or other tools. ;) Now, you need a servo controller. If you're an Arduino fan just like me, check to see http://arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/Knob. Modeling your gears in Blender
  • Ensure if you were enabled the 'Extra Objects' Addon. Check to see http://curriculum.makerbot.com/daily_tutorial/blender/blender_06.html
  • Measrure your center distance and try some values. :) If you want more detailed gear descriptions, see http://www.roymech.co.uk/Useful_Tables/Drive/Gears.html
  • Add gear meshes and fix them into solid meshes. Check to see http://maskedretriever.com/solid_cg/survival_02.htm
    • In my case, center distance is 26mm. Servo horn diameter is 24mm. Lens diameter is 14mm.
    I've tried two gear ratio designs. 1:1 gears and 1:1.5 gears. And my final choice is 1:1.5 gear ratio.
    If you have longer center distrance you are so lucky. Servos are limited in rotation angles, you know. More gearing ratio will increase the focal length ranges. Blender 3D gear parameters
    ==servo gear ==
    Number of teeth: 15
    Radius: 15.0
    Width: 2.0
    Base: 1.5
    Dedendum: 1.0
    Addendum: 2.0
    Pressure Angle: 20.0
    others: 0.0
    == lens gear ==
    Number of teeth: 10
    Radius: 10.0
    Width: 3.0
    others: same above. And to make them solid, I did followings.
    FYI, see http://www.katsbits.com/tutorials/blender/learning-modeling-mesh-editing.php first if you are not familliar to the Blender 3D.
    == Lens gear ==
  • Right click the gear to select.
  • Press [Tab] key to enter Edit mode.
  • Press [A] key to toggle Deselect/select all. Press several [A]'s to ensure nothing selected.
  • Click the Edge select mode icon. See http://www.katsbits.com/images/tutorials/blender-make-simple-chair/blender-select-mode-vertex-edge-face.jpg
  • Select one of the most internal edge from upper surface then click 'select/edge loop' menu. Then you'll get circular edge selection.
  • Press [Shift] key to add one of the most internal edge from down surface then select edge loop, again.
  • Now you should get two edge loops. Click mesh/Edge/Bridge two Edge Loops menu. This will make your two edge loops into an cylinderical shape which will hold your lens.
  • Press [Tab] key to leave Edit mode - means you will be in the Object mode.
    • == Servo gear ==
  • Right click the gear to select.
  • [Tab] to enter the Edit mode.
  • Press several [A]'s to select nothing.
  • Click the Edge select mode icon.
  • Select one of the most internal edge from down surface then click select/Edge loop menu.
  • Press [S] key to sclae your loop. Enter "0.3" to scale it. Now it looks like there's a hole in your bottom surface.
  • Just click one of the most internal edge from upper surface then click select/Edge loop menu.
  • Press [E] to extrude then enter "0 [TAB] 0 [TAB] -2". This will make the loop extude 2mm down along Z axis.
  • Press [E] to extrude then just enter [Esc] to make loop duplicated. Or you will got an wege not an plate with next step.
  • Press [S] key to sclae the loop. Enter "0.3" to scale it. Now it looks like there's a plate having a hole in the middle of your gear.
  • Press [Shift] key to add one of the most internal edge from down surface then select edge loop, again.
  • Now you should get two internal edge loops. Click mesh/Edge/Bridge Two Edge Loops menu.
    • Congratulations! Now, you've got two solid gears.

remixed_from.title: Linbin Screwless Borderless Stackable Labelable V2 3mm

description.text:
This is a remix of litwan's stackable Linbin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:224587 This version has been made narrower, making it more suitable for smaller stuff (screws, etc). I also made it a little bit shorter because it looked a little bit ridiculous otherwise. The external dimensions of this Linbin are 60mm wide, 78mm tall (including the stacking lugs), and 180mm deep. For comparison, litwan's linbin is approximately 100mm wide and 90mm tall. I've uploaded two files:

  • Linbin-Small-Single Is the cut pattern for a single bin. Useful if you only want to make a couple or only have a small laser cutter

  • Linbin-Small-Four Cut pattern to make four bins at once. Laid out to reduce waste, but you need a bigger laser cutter.
Just cut on a laser cutter with 3mm MDF or Acrylic or whatever.

title: soporte posterior cesta portaobjetos Decathlon Btwin - External support from Decathlon Btwin front bike basket

description.text:
la cesta de BTWIN  en decathlon lleva un anclaje que en caso de golpe suele romper.  He creado este para la cesta de mi novia que rompio el  otro dia y encaja bien. Va ya vaciado por debajo , imprimir al 100% de densidad ya que tiene que ser resistente.  
Incluyo archivo original solidwoks por si alguien quiere hacer modificaciones.  
Decathlon Btwin bike basket have a plastic support on their back wich in case of being hit brokes easily.  This part is already emptied from its back , print it with 100% density because it have to be strong enough because of the vibrations when biking.
Solidworks file included to make modifications as needed.

These parts replace the camera holder and laser mounts for the Ciclop 3D scanner in order to make it compatible with FreeLSS, which uses a Raspberry Pi rather than an Arduino and has different geometry requirements for the camera and lasers. They are designed to be combined with the Ciclop turntable in order to make a complete scanner. A series of blog posts describing the project begins here. Please note that this is very much a work in progress and the design, especially the camera holder, will likely be revised. I'm releasing the design now because a few people have asked for the parts, but if you print them now be aware that they may not be fully functional.

This is a remix of Knife Switch of LoboCNC's Frankenstein Light Switch Plate.  I took his original one and split it in half so you can double print and put them together so both sides have a finished look.  I also separated the knob so it can be printed in a different color.  
I will also be making a version for the 2 and 3 gang version in the near future.  
I made a modification to the stub the knob fits on as the first one was misaligned.  I haven't reprinted the new one yet but will in the next day or so.  
2/12/15: Printed the new files to test the stub and the knob slips right on now.  Might need a drop of glue depending on how tight it is on yours.  
2/13/15: Added the narrower xN version for the 2, 3 and 4 gang version.

Print two KnifeSwitch.stl and one Knob.stl.  The KnifeSwitch has holes that a short piece of 1.75mm filament can be inserted.  This can be used to help aligning the parts when gluing.  The knob slips on and is held in place by friction.

comments.text: I loved the Frankenstein Light Switch Plate but not the paddle so much.  This makes the paddle so much more customizable.  I am printing the plate in grey, the main paddle in black and the knob in Glow-In-Dark filament.  This kids will love this :)

This is a simple mounting system for a fan. It was designed for a MakerBot Thing-O-Matic. I am pretty sure it will work for a cupcake. I needed some simple solution while I wait for my MK6 stepstruder. I was trying to print cube gears by Emmett http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6073 (observe picture: Black print before fan, Blue print after fan). Anyway, I needed something easier to install, adjust, repoint and remove than Around the Nozzle Cooling http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6173 by Scanlime or Ducted fan http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5756 by Iwo, which are far better solutions than this. But from my understanding, I won't need it with the stepper extruder because of the 'cool' skeinforge plugin.

You can use Quarter inch dowels to put it together or you can do what I did and get Plastruct polystyrene rods, which I linked to at the bottom or go to your hobby store, every one I have been to has a Plastruct Polystyrene stand. You will also need the 6 bolts and 6 nuts listed. The square bracket and the two rod mounting thingies in Fan-1-mount.stl connect the fan to the rods. The parts in Fan-2-Mount connect the bracket to the Z platform. Just look at this pictures, you'll figure it out. I don't have my fan controller hooked up right now, because I don't have it yet. Make sure when you cut the rods, you mind where the Z-platform is going, don't make them too long, or you'll bang it into something when the bot prints. I don't have exact measurements, but the Rod going X wise is about 16 CM. The two rods going in the Y direction are about 8 - 10 cm. The connectors could probably be made alot smaller but this was a temporary solution and I am probably not going to fix it. It works perfectly like it is. Of course around the nozzle cooling or ducted fan would be better, because this doesn't reach the back of the print too well and it cools the nozzle having the fan blow on it. And these might be a better solution too: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6758 or the classic http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6471 .

comments.text: You've dropped the belt on your ABP.  I did the same thing and got the same result (with heart gears).  You don't necessarily need a fan:  I just turned the heat down to 100C and the gears print fine.  I think the slight airgap of the belt prevents the overhang of the gears from getting as melty.  With direct Kapton there's much more heat radiated up.

I had lowered my HBP temperature to 100 like you suggested in those comments. I don't know if it would have worked or not, because I wasn't getting good print to platform adhesion at that temperature. At 130 degrees, my prints need to be removed from the build surface with a prybar.

title: Inductive Sensor Auto-leveling Mod for Makerfarm Kits

description.text:
Inductive Auto-leveling Modification for Makerfarm kits with Mount included. This requires swapping out one 15mm M3 screw for a 20mm M3 on the extruder carriage. You'll need:
firmware update/change to Marlin to enable Auto-leveling. (Markerfarm uses Marlin)
printed bracket
inductive sensor like this:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/New-LJ12A3-4-Z-BY-Inductive-Proximity-Sensor-Detection-Switch-PNP-DC6-36V-/361213241090?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item5419fca702 In Marlin's config.h you will need to enable the Autoleveling features. It might make more sense to download the newest Marlin and reconfigure it. Makerfarm does not currently host Marlin versions that have auto-leveling enable-able. You'll replace the z-end stop with the sensor which will sense a piece of foil tape on the bed. Marlin's auto-leveling supports the sensing of multiple level points. This mod only uses 4. More updates on this to follow... Thanks! check out our bland website
https://www.protobuilds.com
and less bland facebook page
https://www.facebook.com/protobuilds
More detailed instructions soon...
